title: 111_hr2017
content: The text introduces a new chapter, Chapter 1404, granting a federal charter to the Military Officers Association of America. Chapter 1404 grants a federal charter to the Military Officers Association of America, a nonprofit organization meeting veterans service requirements under section 501(c)(19) of the Internal Revenue Code. The organization is organized under Virginia law and must comply with the provisions of the chapter to maintain its charter. The purposes of the corporation, as outlined in its bylaws and articles of incorporation, include inculcating love for the United States and the flag, defending the Constitution and Government, advocating for adequate military forces, fostering the integrity of the Armed Forces, promoting fraternal relations between branches, educating children of members, and aiding Armed Forces members and their families. The corporation aims to support members of the Armed Forces, including retirees, family members, survivors, and veterans. Membership eligibility and rights are determined by the bylaws. The board of directors' composition and responsibilities are outlined in the articles of incorporation and bylaws. The corporation's officers are elected as per the articles of incorporation and bylaws. It has powers outlined in its bylaws and articles of incorporation. Restrictions include not issuing stock or paying dividends, and income cannot benefit directors or officers. Compensation and expenses can be approved by the board of directors. The corporation, approved by the board of directors, is restricted from making loans to its directors, officers, employees, or members. It cannot claim congressional approval or the authority of the United States Government. The corporation must maintain its status as a corporation incorporated under the laws of Virginia. Failure to maintain tax-exempt status under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will result in the termination of its charter. The corporation is required to keep correct and complete records of account and minutes of proceedings. The corporation must maintain records of proceedings, members entitled to vote, and comply with state laws for service of process. It is liable for acts of officers and agents. The corporation is liable for acts of officers and agents within its authority. It must submit an annual report to Congress on its activities. The term 'State' includes the District of Columbia and US territories. The Military Officers Association of America is identified as "1404. Military Officers Association of America... 140401".
